div1.p: Carter provides camp and family news.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Emma Coleman Carter, October 17, 1888
div1.opener:
MARINE HOSPITAL SERVICE
1798
U. S.
1871
U. S. Marine-Hospital Service,
DISTRICT OF THE GULF,
Port of Ship Island, Miss. Surgeon's Office.
Oct 17, 1888.
Dear Mother
div1.p:
We are all well & doing well. L.
is getting well, but not rapidly. nor was it to be
expected that she would; My “period of incubation” will
be out Wednesday or Thursday. & I don't feel as if I were
going to have the fever. You will know by the time you get
this. The three men got well. one was pretty sick:

The excitement of this week has been my catching a
Devil Fish. I caught one - harpooned him - a very large
one & he towed me about 6 or 7 miles. we pulling a-
gainst him - 4 men - all the time. Sometimes he
sunk the bow of the boat so deep that the rud-
der - I was steering - was clear of the water & I could
not guide her, & sometimes he would go ahead
like a steamer & then run off to one side
so that, although I had one man stand by
with an axe to cut the line if needed, yet
it was ticklish steering- when I found he was go-
ing out to sea. I set sail & carried the line astern
& when the boat pulled up by the wind, the
harpoon pulled out. Three boats were trying.
to help upme, but could not catch up,
we did catch a smaller one- theyhe ran by the other boat & I
threw him (the boat) a line & having 8 oarsmen on
we so impeded his flight that the others caught up.
This one weighed about 2400 to 2800 pounds ( took 8 men in a triple pulley to lift him & his
mouth 2 feet 7 inches in diameter- The size of the
escaping I don't know - but he was a whale. I could not
get my men to go with me- I mean the two I had-
with me-. so I took greenhorns from a vessel here: Not a man
on the island or in any of the crews had ever seen one
dead- an He is a bad looking beast: a mouth a
bout as big as a wash tub & teeth in proportion.
The children were profoundly impressed, & said
that I must “tell Sam & Hugh.” It is always a question with
them “what would Sam think
if he was here
now?”
We are suffering just now from an accident
There was a family of rats who took such an interest in Ed-
ward Champe that L's fears - or jealousy rather - was aroused & I gave
them Arsenic. There are no walls to this place as it is
not lathed & plastered & I thought we were safe, but one was
ingenious to die in the window casing of the next
room & I don't know but he is about even with us,
L. says she is glad that they are dead & I don't like to be un-
sympathetic, but my happiness there at isn't exuber-
ant & uncontrollable, but to a great extent modified by the
manner or rather locality of his demise.

Well Quarantine is drawing to a close - 24 more
days & probably 15 more to 24 but I think not, then I'm going
to have some teeth fixed (pulled?) & then to Fla: af-
ter going to Chandeleur “to see the piece of land” like
the man in the Bible who wanted to be excused.
I could have doubtless done better now than in the spring
but I still think is a good bargain

We are all intending to go to Biloxi on the Arsene, which
is being painted & shaped for the occasion-with all
of her flags up & have “a party”. The thing isn't over
but it seems so to me.

L. says the baby is very good & he is: don't like to
cry apparently: is healthy & digests his food very well,
A ships captain sent him a piece of money today & when
the children saw it in his hand. Laura cryed out, “Oh
Papa, look at Eddy: Do you think he brought that
from “South Beach”, (where he is supposed to have
been cast ashore like all the other “finds” on the
island). “Where could he have hid it”?

Well good night my dear & best love to all,
we rec'd the novels: but can't say that I admire
“Mr. Potter of Texas” which I read when I had a
little (very little) Dysentry Thursday.
div1.closer:
Your affec'ate son H. R. Carter Oct 8: Small boy has indigestion & diarrhoea: but I think he will be all
right shortly you know that isn't uncommon & he has had
none for 2 1/2 or 3 weeks: A northern on us now othe Ther-
mometer at 59° F. this morning
H. R. Carter
